summary: study examined changes in health status of china's adult population between 2003 and 2008 due to rapid economic growth and medical system improvement. results Chinese respondents in 2008 were more likely to report disease than in 2003. smoking slightly decreased among men and women, and regular exercise showed much improvement. a new type of rural cooperative medical care system was piloted in some counties in 2003. coverage rate reached 72.6% by December 2004 and would gradually cover all rural residents by 2010. urban resident basic health insurance scheme in china has covered all cities since 2008. the study provided important information for furthering research questions for future studies. 141,927 (M/F, 70,541/71,386) residents in 2003 and 136,371 (66,801/69,570) in 2008. 94 counties and cities were randomly selected from rural and urban areas. the survey response rate for adults was 83% in 2008 (77.8% in 2003) if there was missing information, probands could be re-surveyed the next day. a 5% sample of households was randomly selected and re-surveyed. two surveys were conducted in the same sampling areas. 94 counties and cities were randomly selected from rural and urban areas. the mainland of china was clustered according to the government administrative geographic system. a 5% sample of households was randomly selected and re-surveyed to examine survey quality by telephone or visit again. there was no age preference in the survey. a similarity coefficient and GINI concentration ratio indicated that family size in the survey was consistent with the established national picture. a difference in composition of some age groups between the two surveys was found between 2003 and 2008. more people in 2008 were divorce and widowed (1.5%, 7.5% 17.5% of Chinese people had been diagnosed with hypertension by medical doctors. the prevalence of hypertension in the Chinese adult population has increased from 5.1% in 1959, to 7.7% in 1980, to 13.6% in 1991, and to 18.8% in 2002. a national education program that can eliminate the huge gaps among presence, awareness, treatment, and ability to control hypertension and diabetes should be given to the public, clinicians, and healthcare decision makers. social determinants of health have become important factors associated with the decline of health status. findings suggest that to promote health status we should focus on elderly and widowed people and promote higher national educational level. prevention strategies such as reduction of tobacco use, exposure to second-hand smoke, less dietary intake of salt and fat should also be prioritized. public health policy should pay explicit attention to these issues. as economic development and environmental degradation continue, systems of disease prevention and health promotion in china will face ever-bigger difficulties and challenges.
